page.title: 14Morwenstow - Fauna
page.content: There are now many rabbits on most farms. Their disappearance due to myxomatosis probably caused the Large Blue butterfly's extinction as cliff grasses grew longer and coarser. These are to be re-introduced from the Continent shortly and stand a good chance of colonising the area again. Foxes are plentiful, and even seen in farmyards. Badgers have been gassed by the Ministry of Agriculture trying to eradicate T. B. in cattle but still many may be seen, also mink, hares and the occasional otter. Deer from Hartland Abbey cross cliff- top farms. Birds include buzzards, kestrel, heron and mallards. barn owls and bats roost by day in the old houses nad buildings and fly by night over the farmyards and fields. There are 35 species of butterfly and 13 of dragonfly.
